comment_text: Hey, I'm Dianna and you're watching Physics Girl. I know, that part of the video is missing. So is HAPPY PHYSICSING! SORRY! Let me explain. This video is part of a PBS Miniseries called Stellar done in collaboration with PBS Spacetime and It's Okay to Be Smart. There will be videos on their channels too, and one more on Physics Girl in 3 weeks. For the context of this video, let's go back to when I was a wee undergrad studying physics. Back then, there were experiments that physicists agreed were potentially going to be HUGE for modern physics - discovering the Higgs boson (we did that recently!), taking the first image of a black hole (we just did that too!). But a really big experiment was aiming to measure gravitational waves, and I remember being told we didn’t know if we’d measure them any time soon, if ever. But in 2015 we measured the first gravitational wave. It was a HUGE moment! Not just for physics, but for all of science! And the observatory that made the discovery was LIGO. For this video, which is part of a PBS space series that i’ll explain more in the description, I GOT TO GO TO LIGO. The best part was sitting with the head of the observatory and asking him all my questions about the universe in the downtime of the shoot. One of the coolest days of my life. Anyways.. I hope you enjoy this series!

Great video! Thanks for the tour and for sharing. The Hanford, WA and Livingston, LA LIGO sites really are worth a visit for folks of any interest level (and the Virgo detector for you all in Italy)!
One interesting question is: how can we trust laser light to tell us information about spacetime shrinking/stretching if the space the laser travels through is also shrinking/stretching? There are two phenomenal explanations of how the interferometer exploits light interference to get gravitational-wave information here:
(Less formal) https://www.forbes.com/sites/startswithabang/2018/09/15/ask-ethan-if-light-contracts-and-expands-with-space-how-do-we-detect-gravitational-waves/#15f516f519a5
(More formal physics paper but still highly readable) https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/393a/af6b1ced305ee40d175d5f3c3a2b6020348d.pdf
They both have essentially the same point on that issue - "it is better to say that we use the laser as a clock than
to say we use its light as a ruler" (from the formal paper). LIGO really is one of the best examples in scientific history of a wild, fascinating idea derived from theory on paper that developed into a full-fledged branch of measurable experimental physics.

It is also thought by some that the most powerful force ever, is that #1 condition of absolutely no matter. It is thought, by at least myself, that the force associated with absolutely no matter can "pull" itself apart, much as a vaccumn (but there really is no such thing as a vaccumn, there is always a lesser pressure giving the effects of a vaccumn). And by pulling itself apart the force creates two general categories of matter that some understand to be matter particles and antimatter particles, thus the building blocks of atoms. Where are these particles of matter and antimatter? Well they're all around, the positron and electron are a matter-antimatter pair and the neutron-proton are also a matter-antimatter pair. Both pairs are "inverse" particles to each other, thus what I mean by matter and antimatter. And gravity is the interaction of a great amount of matter and a lesser amount of matter (or just nothing).

I love your videos, but in this one you don't actually explain specifically how the measurement occurs. The way one beam, or a combination of both in different sequence, expands and contracts from the wave of gravity that washes over it. Looking at how all these 4 beams, 2 in each detector, expand and contract allows us to triangulate where and when a gravity wave originates. And hence, what it was that produced it.

Correct me if I'm wrong, but gravitational waves are not really anything special, right?
I mean, they are, but isn't it just the force of gravity being weaker when the object (eg: one of the black holes) is slightly further away, and the force being slightly larger when it gets closer? Further, closer, further, closer in a wave pattern as they orbit, just like moving two magnets closer and further from each other, and calling it a magnetic wave.
So it's just variations in the force of gravity, and not a real wave, like electromagnetic waves. But, then again, electromagnetic waves are just vibrations as an electron settles back into its orbit, or whatever, so.. yea.
Basically what I mean is that when people hear of gravitational waves, they think that we have discovered how gravity works, when really we're just measuring differing distances, albeit really quickly. I'm not saying it isn't a fantastic achievement or anything, because it is.
